item.title: By: infinitearchive

item.description:
Do you happen to know if there is any relationship between the terms: 'Avodah Zarah' (mentioned in your article), and the name 'Zarah' (a Child of Judah and Tamar)?
I am concerned that the concept of 'Avodah Zarah', may tend to make a group 'clannish'. How can the doctrines of the Great Patriarchs, bless the nations - and yet still be clannish - at the same time?
Do you accept the notion, that the descendants of Zarah, made it to England? http://www.google.com/search?rlz=1C1GPCK_enUS372US372&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&q=zerah+judah+

item.title: By: MBG
item.dc:creator: MBG
item.content:encoded:
” The obvious answer is that the common ground of family values, conservative politics, and banning gay marriage overcomes little things like the principles of faith.”

As I think was at least alluded to in the comments to the previous post, I think it is more subtle than that. What you list applies to many protestant groups as well.
But with Mormons, there is also commonality in (1) having a religion with a fairly complicated and obscure-to-outsiders set of rules and practices, about which one has been the target of ill-will and persecution in the recent past and for which one therefore mostly wants to be left alone (by both secularists and evangelicals) rather than evangelize/publicize, and (2) being a (generally) white-looking religious minority (seemingly?) overrepresented in the well-paying professions.

(I realize the mormom mission goes against what i say re: “rather than evangelize,” but I think it is still true that in american politics mormons have a “leave us and our peculiarities alone” streak rather than a “be like us and adopt our pecluiarities” streak.)
